title: Boris Johnson in bizarre PMQs rant after Corbyn confronts him with mum's death
text:

Boris Johnson launched a bizarre, rambling rant claiming Jeremy Corbyn should "apologise" after Labour's leader confronted him with the death of an elderly mum.

The flustered Tory leader embarked on an unrelated diatribe about Russia and nationalised trains after Mr Corbyn raised the case of a woman called Gillian.

In the final PMQs before the December 12 general election , Mr Corbyn read out a letter from Gillian which arrived this week.

It said: "My mother died in February as a direct result of the GP shortage in the UK. Her last years were marred by long waits for treatments and interventions.

"Whenever she got care it was given by overstretched and very dedicated people but it always came after painful and debilitating delays”.

Mr Corbyn added: "Why should that happen to Gillian’s mum or anyone else’s mum?

(Image: Sky News)

"The problem is the shortage of GPs, the shortage of nurses and the excessive waiting time for people with very difficult conditions and deep pain.

"They should be sympathised with and supported."

Mr Johnson stuttered as he answered at first: "I can certainly say that we will deal with his constituent Gillian's concerns."

Incredulous Labour MPs shouted: "Her mother died! Listen!"

Then he went immediately on the attack - saying: "There are 17,300 more doctors and over 17,000 more nurses on our wards since 2010.

"And I think frankly it is time to differentiate between the politics of protest and the politics of leadership.

"And he should apologise for continually striking attitudes that I do not think are interests of the... [tails off].

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"It's all very easy to be an Islingtonian protester and say you side with Russia over what happened in Salisbury or to say you have a £196bn programme of renationalisation or continually to flip flop one way or the other, now leave now remain, refusing to respect the verdict of the people in the referendum on the EU.

"Leadership means standing up for the people of this country, standing up for our police, standing up for our NHS, making sure it gets the funding it needs and standing up for our economy and for our wealth creators and above all it means getting Brexit done and ending dither and delay

"The time for protest is over, it's time for leadership."

The £196bn figure Mr Johnson quoted is from a study by the CBI business body that claimed Labour's nationalisation plans would cost at least £196billion.

However, the Full Fact website concluded that it failed to factor in the economic benefits of nationalisation, and said its method was disputed.

The CBI also admitted an error over the assumption that rail carriages would be moved to public ownership, which "isn't official Labour policy".

Labour would also question Mr Johnson's claims about the NHS.

An analysis in May by the respected Nuffield Trust said the number of GPs per 100,000 people fell from nearly 65 in 2014 to 60 last year.

Meanwhile the number of nurses, midwives ad nursing associates registered to work in the UK is at an all-time high, according to the NMC, but the body warned of "high vacancy and turnover rates".

The pair clashed over a string of NHS figures as Mr Corbyn chose to focus on the health service in a pre-election message.

(Image: WPA Pool)

Mr Corbyn said: "The Prime Minister's planned sell-out deal with Donald Trump means yet more National Health Service money being siphoned off into private profit.

"Channel 4 Dispatches reported that the cost of drugs and medicines has repeatedly been discussed between UK and US trade representatives.

"Why did the Prime Minister say the health service wasn't on the table in any post-Brexit trade deal?"

Mr Johnson replied: "The answer to that is very simple, it is because it is not on the table."

He continued: "If he wants to know how the people of this country are able to afford the stupendous investments that we're now making in the NHS, £34 billion, the biggest ever investment in the NHS, 40 new hospitals that we are building as a result of the decisions we are taking - it is because this is the party that supports wealth creation."

Mr Johnson added: "And the reason we're able to invest in the NHS is because for the last nine years this economy has been growing. It has grown by 19% since the Conservatives first came into office, and he would ruin this economy and ruin our ability to fund the NHS, and that is the reality."

Mr Corbyn said: "We learned this week that Government officials have met US pharmaceutical companies five times as part of the Prime Minister's planned trade detail. The US has called for full market access to our NHS, which would mean prices of some of our most important medicines increasing by up to seven fold.

"Whilst the Government is having secret meetings with US corporations, it is patients here that continue to suffer."

Mr Johnson replied: "Are you seriously suggesting that the NHS should not engage in negotiations to ensure British patients get the drugs they deserve? Are you so phobic of American companies that you will forbid them from having these discussions?"

Mr Corbyn said: "Of course we need to import medicines from various places. I just want it to be done in an open and transparent way. I don't want secret talks between Government officials on behalf of ministers with big pharma corporations in the USA."

Mr Corbyn said last year 34,000 cancer patients waited more than two months for treatment.

He said the longer people wait, the lower the chances of surviving cancer. He called for more resources to cut waiting times.

Mr Johnson replied: "We intend, if we are allowed, if we come back as the next government, we will invest massively in that NHS and take it forward with the funds that we will make available from a strong and growing economy, and the reality is he would wreck that economy."
description: Furious MPs shouted "her mother died!" in the last PMQs before the general election after the Tory claimed he'd "deal with" the case - and said Jeremy Corbyn should "apologise"
